channel.title: Jar Archives
channel.description: I'm having trouble creating and unpacking jars. I would appreciate it greatly if someone would tell me what I should be putting into my command line to archive a jar and to unarchive it. Thanks in advance :D

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

Awesome, I think I’ve gotten it down now Thanks again!

Read full topic

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

You type in the manifest “Main-Class:<your main class, the one with main(String args[]) in it>” + ENTER, and pack with the cvfm. Cvfm stores a manifest (excecutable), cf doesn’t (not executable).

Read full topic

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

Aha! Thank you both very much. That makes a great deal more sense.
However, what do you type in the manifest file to specify which main command to execute?

And just to reiterate, -cf only stores, cvfm makes it executable, right?

Read full topic

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

Yeah, he’s right. I was only assuming that you wanted the same deployment as, say, mopar’s private server client. “jar cvfm manifest.txt Test.jar *.class” puts all of the class files in the folder you’re using into the jar. . puts every thing else as well, and I think that’d either make the jar too big or expose your source code. However you can do whatever you like because it’s your stuff. Specifying a main class in the manifest only makes the jar executable.

Read full topic

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

It will take any files you like You don’t have to specify a manifest file if you aren’t planning on running directly from the jar. For example, if you wanted to put everything from a folder into a jar, you could do:

jar -cf myJar.jar *.*

Read full topic

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

Oh so is that all a bat file will do?
It just executes a command similar to a command prompt execution?

Where is it exactly that you put the name of the files you wish to compress into the archive? Is that in the .txt file as

Main-Class: <java files>

And does that take only class files or will it take java files as well? Thanks again

Read full topic

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

The bat is doing the same thing as putting “jar cvfm manifest.txt Test.jar *.class” into the command prompt. The text file is constructing the manifest (if you unpack the jar you’ll find a folder named META-INF, with MANIFEST.MF inside, which is the instructions to execute your main class when you do “java -jar yourjar.jar”)[br][size=1]Posted at: July 09, 2006, 09:14:44 PM[/size][hr]Oh, and I don’t remember exactly what cvfm does, but it’s some combination of option flags. If you go into cmd and just type jar, you can find exactly what these are.

Read full topic

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @aznph8playa aznph8playa
item.description:
@aznph8playa wrote:

Ah ok, thanks so much. Do you think you could explain to me exactly what the bat and text files are doing though? I’m assuming that the text file is specifying which classes are to be packaged into the .jar but how do you specify more than one?
Also, what exactly does cvfm do? And is there a way to unpackage using java and cmd prompt? Again, thanks. I’m just full of questions and I’m glad you’re willing to help me out

Read full topic

item.title: Jar Archives
item.dc:creator: @White_Castle White Castle
item.description:
@White_Castle wrote:

I’ve posted this before:

First make a text file called manifest.txt:

[code]Main-Class: Test

[/code]

Note: the enter after Main-Class is essential!

Then make a bat file:

@echo off jar cvfm manifest.txt Test.jar *.class pause

And then run the bat file![br][size=1]Posted at: July 09, 2006, 06:13:07 PM[/size][hr]Oh and to unpack just use WinRar.

Read full topic
